action.action-desc: Mr. Frost (for himself and Ms. Matsui) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committees on Education and Workforce, and Ways and Means, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To amend title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to establish requirements with respect to cost sharing for epinephrine delivery systems under group health plans and group and individual health insurance coverage.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Epinephrine’s Pharma Inflated Price Ends Now Act or the EPIPEN Act.

section.header: Requirements with respect to cost sharing for epinephrine delivery systems

subsection.text: Part D of title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 300gg–111 et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following new section:

section.header: Requirements with respect to cost sharing for epinephrine delivery systems

subsection.text: A group health plan, and a health insurance issuer offering group or individual health insurance coverage, shall provide coverage of epinephrine delivery systems, and with respect to such delivery systems, may not—

paragraph.text: impose any cost sharing in excess of $60 per package of 2 delivery systems (or the equivalent).

subsection.header: Application of cost sharing toward deductibles and out-of-Pocket maximums
subsection.text: Any cost-sharing payments made pursuant to subsection (a)(2) shall be counted toward any deductible or out-of-pocket maximum that applies under the plan or coverage.

Nothing in this section requires a plan or issuer that has a network of providers to provide benefits for an epinephrine delivery system described in this section that is delivered by an out-of-network provider, or precludes a plan or issuer that has a network of providers from imposing higher cost sharing than the levels specified in subsection (a)(2) for an epinephrine delivery system described in this section that is delivered by an out-of-network provider.

In this section, the term epinephrine delivery system means a delivery system approved by the Food and Drug Administration for the administration of epinephrine, including any auto-injector, nasal spray, or sublingual delivery system that is so approved.

subsection.text: The amendments made by this section shall apply with respect to plan years beginning on or after January 1, 2026.
